Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell 
you their actual preference. Here’s what happens: you poll 200 voters, and 130 say 
they’ll vote for the troll. For about 50%, or 100 of them,
the coin will have landed heads. So you can subtract 100 troll votes 
off his total, and know the troll’s real support 
is 30 to 70, and he’s very likely to lose. The election comes around,
but before the results can be certified a third party candidate swoops in 
and burns the treefellow to a crisp. The freshly signed and deeply flawed
constitution mandates that this challenger gets to take his victim’s place 
in a new election. The Dormor Polling Agency sends you back 
out on the streets with your trusty coin. Only this time no one is comfortable
admitting their preference: supporting the troll is still shameful, and nobody wants to express support of a
dragon who murdered his way into the race. But your job is your job. 
How do you conduct an accurate poll now? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 This time, instead of masking 
just one candidate preference, you need some way to disguise both. At the same time, you also need to leave 
space for some portion of the people polled to express their true preference. But a coin toss only has two
possible outcomes... right? Suppose you have everyone
flip the coin twice— now there are four possible results. You can tell the people who flip heads
twice in a row to report support for the troll; those who get tails 
twice in a row to report dragon; and those with any other combination
to declare their true preference. The chances of getting either
two heads or two tails in a row are 50% times 50%— 
or 25%. Subtracting that proportion 
of the total respondents from each candidate’s score should 
give you something close to the real distribution. This time, 105 respondents announced 
themselves in favor of the troll and 95 for the dragon. Out of the total, the coin will make 25% or 50 respond troll 
and another 50 respond dragon. Subtracting 50 from each result reveals
that voters seem to prefer the troll by a margin of about 55 to 45. It’s close, but as predicted,
the troll wins the election, and you live to poll another day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are three candidates A, B, C. You poll 800 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin three times. If the coin comes up heads all three times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails all three times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 25% of the people like A and 40% like B and 35% like C, approximately what poll score will A receive?
Options: A. 190, B. 250, C. 370, D. 600
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method did the Dormor Polling Agency use to disguise the true preference of troll supporters in the first election? Options: A. They asked voters to flip a coin to determine their response., B. They used a secret handshake to identify troll supporters., C. They asked voters to report their true preference without any disguise., D. They used a complex mathematical formula to determine voter preferences. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the result of subtracting the number of respondents who were influenced by the coin from the total number of votes for the troll in the first election? Options: A. The troll's real support was 80-20., B. The troll's real support was 30-70., C. The troll's real support was 50-50., D. The troll's real support was 20-80. Correct Option: B

Because the first method was too simple., C. Because the first method was not effective in disguising voter preferences., D. Because the first method was not cost-effective. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the new method used by the Dormor Polling Agency to disguise voter preferences in the second election? Options: A. They asked voters to flip a coin twice to determine their response., B. They used a random number generator to determine voter preferences., C. They asked voters to report their true preference without any disguise., D. They used a complex mathematical formula to determine voter preferences. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the result of subtracting the number of respondents who were influenced by the coin from the total number of votes for the troll in the second election? Options: A. The troll's real support was 80-20., B. The troll's real support was 30-70., C. The troll's real support was 55-45., D. The troll's real support was 20-80. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are three candidates A, B, C. You poll 800 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin three times. If the coin comes up heads all three times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails all three times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 25% of the people like A and 40% like B and 35% like C, approximately what poll score will B receive?
Options: A. 340, B. 370, C. 750, D. 120
Correct Option: A

you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

They asked voters to flip a coin to determine their response., B. They used a secret handshake to identify troll supporters., C. They asked voters to report their true preference without any disguise., D. They used a complex mathematical formula to determine voter preferences. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the result of subtracting the number of respondents who were influenced by the coin from the total number of votes for the troll in the first election? Options: A. The troll's real support was 80-20., B. The troll's real support was 30-70., C. The troll's real support was 50-50., D. The troll's real support was 20-80. Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why did the Dormor Polling Agency need to find a new method to disguise voter preferences in the second election? Options: A. Because the first method was too complex., B. Because the first method was too simple., C. Because the first method was not effective in disguising voter preferences., D. Because the first method was not cost-effective. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the new method used by the Dormor Polling Agency to disguise voter preferences in the second election? Options: A. They asked voters to flip a coin twice to determine their response., B. They used a random number generator to determine voter preferences., C. They asked voters to report their true preference without any disguise., D. They used a complex mathematical formula to determine voter preferences. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the result of subtracting the number of respondents who were influenced by the coin from the total number of votes for the troll in the second election? Options: A. The troll's real support was 80-20., B. The troll's real support was 30-70., C. The troll's real support was 55-45., D. The troll's real support was 20-80. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of the second election? Options: A. The troll won the election., B. The dragon won the election., C. The election was a tie., D. The election was cancelled. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the reason for the dragon's victory in the second election? Options: A. Because the troll was unpopular., B. Because the dragon was more popular., C. Because the dragon murdered his way into the race., D. Because the dragon was more experienced. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the role of the Dormor Polling Agency in the second election? Options: A. They conducted a poll to determine voter preferences., B. They campaigned for the troll., C. They campaigned for the dragon., D. They did not participate in the election. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the result of the election after the dragon murdered the treefellow? Options: A. The troll won the election., B. The dragon won the election., C. The election was cancelled., D. The election was postponed. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What was the reason for the troll's victory in the second election? Options: A. Because the troll was more popular., B. Because the dragon was unpopular., C. Because the dragon murdered his way into the race., D. Because the troll was more experienced. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

The generated MCQs do not have a similar question, but some of them deal with the concept of using a coin toss to disguise voter preferences.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 4, which asks about the new method used by the Dormor Polling Agency to disguise voter preferences in the second election. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences 
between these options? And which one’s best? Gasoline is refined from crude oil, a fossil fuel extracted
from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use
them interchangeably. Fuels derived from crude oil
are extremely energy dense, bringing a lot of bang for your buck. Unfortunately, they have many drawbacks. Oil spills cause environmental damage
and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning 
fossil fuels like these kills 4.5 million people each year. And transportation accounts for 16%
of global greenhouse gas emissions, almost half of which comes 
from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,
storms caused by climate change caused $500 billion of damage 
in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive 
than gas-powered cars, but the cost difference has been
shrinking rapidly since 2010. The other alternatives to gasoline
are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored
using the same infrastructure as gasoline, and used in the same cars. They can also be carbon-neutral 
if they’re made using carbon dioxide from the atmosphere— meaning when we burn them, we release that
same carbon dioxide back into the air, and don't add to overall emissions. One approach to carbon-neutral fuel
is to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combine its carbon
with the hydrogen in water. This creates hydrocarbons, 
the source of energy in fossil fuels— but without any emissions if the fuels 
are made using clean electricity. These fuels take up more space than an energetically equivalent
amount of gasoline— an obstacle to using them in cars. Another approach is to make carbon-neutral
fuels from plants, which sequester carbon from the air 
through photosynthesis. But growing the plants also has 
to be carbon neutral— which rules out many crops
that require fertilizer, a big contributor 
to greenhouse gas emissions. So the next generation of these fuels
must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a drawback of using fuels from crude oil?
Options: A. Oil spills and costly environmental damage, B. Air pollution that causes health risks, C. Greenhouse gas emissions, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of energy in gasoline? Options: A. Hydrogen in water, B. Crude oil, C. Electricity, D. Carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main drawback of using fossil fuels like gasoline? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They have many environmental and health drawbacks, C. They are expensive to produce, D. They are not suitable for all types of vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary difference between electric cars and gas-powered cars? Options: A. Electric cars are more expensive, B. Electric cars use a battery pack and electric motor instead of an internal combustion engine, C. Electric cars can only be charged at home, D. Electric cars are not as efficient as gas-powered cars Correct Option: B
Question 4: How can carbon-neutral fuels be made? Options: A. By capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combining it with hydrogen in water, B. By using fossil fuels that have been refined from crude oil, C. By growing plants that sequester carbon from the air through photosynthesis, D. By using electricity generated from fossil fuels Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main obstacle to using carbon-neutral fuels in cars? Options: A. They are not as efficient as gasoline, B. They take up more space than an energetically equivalent amount of gasoline, C. They are not suitable for all types of vehicles, D. They are too expensive Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the green premium, and why is it a problem? Options: A. The green premium is the cost difference between green technologies and fossil-fuel-based technologies, and it is a problem because it makes green technologies more expensive for consumers, B. The green premium is the cost difference between fossil-fuel-based technologies and green technologies, and it is a problem because it makes fossil-fuel-based technologies more expensive for consumers, C. The green premium is the cost difference between green technologies and fossil-fuel-based technologies, and it is not a problem, D. The green premium is the cost difference between fossil-fuel-based technologies and green technologies, and it is not a problem Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is one way that governments can help make green technologies more affordable for consumers? Options: A. By subsidizing the production of fossil fuels, B. By subsidizing the production of green technologies, C. By imposing taxes on green technologies, D. By imposing taxes on fossil fuels Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between the cost of electricity and the cost of gas, and how does it affect the affordability of electric cars? Options: A. The cost of electricity is always higher than the cost of gas, so electric cars are never cheaper than gas-powered cars, B. The cost of electricity is always lower than the cost of gas, so electric cars are always cheaper than gas-powered cars, C. The cost of electricity and the cost of gas can vary depending on the location, and this can affect the affordability of electric cars, D. The cost of electricity and the cost of gas have no relationship to the affordability of electric cars Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the potential impact of using carbon-neutral fuels on the environment? Options: A. It will increase greenhouse gas emissions and contribute to climate change, B. It will have no impact on the environment, C. It will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help to mitigate climate change, D. It will increase the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main challenge facing innovators who are trying to bring down the green premium? Options: A. The high upfront costs of implementing new technologies, B. The lack of demand for green technologies, C. The difficulty of making green technologies more affordable for consumers, D. The lack of government support for green technologies Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, as both questions are asking about the drawbacks of using fossil fuels like gasoline. The options for Question 2 also align with the ground truth MCQ, as option B mentions environmental and health drawbacks, which is similar to the correct option D in the ground truth MCQ that mentions oil spills, air pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. 

While Question 2 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match among the generated MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences

from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class

to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use

in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative

double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity

from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use

and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning

from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,

in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive

are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored

Correct Option: B

must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Green premium is ______.
Options: A. A subsidy provided by the government, B. The cost of plant-based fuels, C. The cost difference between a clean technology and its fossil-fuel-based counterpart, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of energy in gasoline? Options: A. Hydrogen in water, B. Crude oil, C. Electricity, D. Carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main drawback of using fossil fuels like gasoline? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They have many environmental and health drawbacks, C. They are expensive to produce, D. They are not suitable for all types of vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary difference between electric cars and gas-powered cars? Options: A. Electric cars are more expensive, B. Electric cars use a battery pack and electric motor instead of an internal combustion engine, C. Electric cars can only be charged at home, D. Electric cars are not as efficient as gas-powered cars Correct Option: B
Question 4: How can carbon-neutral fuels be made? Options: A. By capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combining it with hydrogen in water, B. By using fossil fuels that have been refined from crude oil, C. By growing plants that sequester carbon from the air through photosynthesis, D. By using electricity generated from fossil fuels Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main obstacle to using carbon-neutral fuels in cars? Options: A. They are not as efficient as gasoline, B. They take up more space than an energetically equivalent amount of gasoline, C. They are not suitable for all types of vehicles, D. They are too expensive Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the green premium, and why is it a problem? Options: A. The green premium is the cost difference between green technologies and fossil-fuel-based technologies, and it is a problem because it makes green technologies more expensive for consumers, B. The green premium is the cost difference between fossil-fuel-based technologies and green technologies, and it is a problem because it makes fossil-fuel-based technologies more expensive for consumers, C. The green premium is the cost difference between green technologies and fossil-fuel-based technologies, and it is not a problem, D. The green premium is the cost difference between fossil-fuel-based technologies and green technologies, and it is not a problem Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is one way that governments can help make green technologies more affordable for consumers? Options: A. By subsidizing the production of fossil fuels, B. By subsidizing the production of green technologies, C. By imposing taxes on green technologies, D. By imposing taxes on fossil fuels Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between the cost of electricity and the cost of gas, and how does it affect the affordability of electric cars? Options: A. The cost of electricity is always higher than the cost of gas, so electric cars are never cheaper than gas-powered cars, B. The cost of electricity is always lower than the cost of gas, so electric cars are always cheaper than gas-powered cars, C. The cost of electricity and the cost of gas can vary depending on the location, and this can affect the affordability of electric cars, D. The cost of electricity and the cost of gas have no relationship to the affordability of electric cars Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the potential impact of using carbon-neutral fuels on the environment? Options: A. It will increase greenhouse gas emissions and contribute to climate change, B. It will have no impact on the environment, C. It will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help to mitigate climate change, D. It will increase the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main challenge facing innovators who are trying to bring down the green premium? Options: A. The high upfront costs of implementing new technologies, B. The lack of demand for green technologies, C. The difficulty of making green technologies more affordable for consumers, D. The lack of government support for green technologies Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences 
between these options? And which one’s best? Gasoline is refined from crude oil, a fossil fuel extracted
from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use
them interchangeably. Fuels derived from crude oil
are extremely energy dense, bringing a lot of bang for your buck. Unfortunately, they have many drawbacks. Oil spills cause environmental damage
and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning 
fossil fuels like these kills 4.5 million people each year. And transportation accounts for 16%
of global greenhouse gas emissions, almost half of which comes 
from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,
storms caused by climate change caused $500 billion of damage 
in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive 
than gas-powered cars, but the cost difference has been
shrinking rapidly since 2010. The other alternatives to gasoline
are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored
using the same infrastructure as gasoline, and used in the same cars. They can also be carbon-neutral 
if they’re made using carbon dioxide from the atmosphere— meaning when we burn them, we release that
same carbon dioxide back into the air, and don't add to overall emissions. One approach to carbon-neutral fuel
is to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combine its carbon
with the hydrogen in water. This creates hydrocarbons, 
the source of energy in fossil fuels— but without any emissions if the fuels 
are made using clean electricity. These fuels take up more space than an energetically equivalent
amount of gasoline— an obstacle to using them in cars. Another approach is to make carbon-neutral
fuels from plants, which sequester carbon from the air 
through photosynthesis. But growing the plants also has 
to be carbon neutral— which rules out many crops
that require fertilizer, a big contributor 
to greenhouse gas emissions. So the next generation of these fuels
must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The best fuel is _______.
Options: A. Electrofuel, B. Affordable and sustainable, C. Produced through photosynthesis, D. Water-based hydrocarbon
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
No matter how we make electricity,
it takes up space. Electricity from coal requires mines,
and plants to burn it and convert the heat into electricity. Nuclear power takes uranium mines,
facilities to refine the uranium, a reactor, and a place to store 
the spent fuel safely. Renewable energy needs wind turbines 
or solar panels. How much space depends
on the power source. Say you wanted to power a 10-watt 
light bulb with fossil fuels like coal. Fossil fuels can produce 
up to 2,000 watts per square meter, so it would only take a credit card-sized
chunk of land to power the light bulb. With nuclear power, you might only
need an area about the size of the palms of your hands. With solar power, you’d need at least
0.3 square meters of land— twice the size of a cafeteria tray. Wind power would take roughly
7 square meters— about half the size of a parking space— 
to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost
four times as much space at a minimum— roughly 4,000 square kilometers, 
a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce electricity from nuclear power, we need ________.
Options: A. Uranium mines, B. To burn plants, C. Solar panels, D. Wind turbine
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why electricity from any source requires space? Options: A. Because electricity generation involves the burning of fossil fuels., B. Because electricity generation requires the conversion of heat into electricity., C. Because electricity generation takes up physical space for equipment and infrastructure., D. Because electricity generation involves the storage of electrical energy. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, how much space would be required to power a 10-watt light bulb with fossil fuels like coal? Options: A. A square meter, B. A credit card-sized chunk of land, C. The size of a parking space, D. The area of Grand Bahama island Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the approximate area required to power the entire world with only fossil fuels? Options: A. 1,000 square kilometers, B. 1,200 square kilometers, C. 4,000 square kilometers, D. 95,000 square kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, how does the space needed for wind power generation vary compared to other power sources? Options: A. Wind power requires the most space of all power sources., B. Wind power requires the least space of all power sources., C. Wind power requires a significant amount of space, but not as much as nuclear power., D. Wind power requires space to be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 5: What are the two main considerations for choosing a power source, according to the transcript? Options: A. Space and cost, B. Space and greenhouse gas emissions, C. Cost and reliability, D. Space and availability Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the main challenge with relying on fossil fuels as a power source? Options: A. They require too much space., B. They are too expensive to build., C. They contribute to greenhouse gas emissions and climate change., D. They are not available in some places. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the amount of space needed for wind power generation and the efficiency of the turbines? Options: A. The more space, the higher the efficiency., B. The less space, the higher the efficiency., C. The space needed does not affect the efficiency of the turbines., D. The space needed must be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the best option for replacing fossil fuels in some places? Options: A. Nuclear power, B. Solar power, C. Wind power, D. A combination of power sources Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main consideration for making power sources better, according to the transcript? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increasing efficiency, C. Improving safety, D. Reducing costs Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the approximate percentage of greenhouse gas emissions that come from electricity generation? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 27%, D. 50% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it doesn't exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose one, I would say that the closest match is not present, but if I had to choose from the given options, I would say Question 1 is the closest.

But since Question 1 doesn't exactly match the ground truth MCQ, I will try to find another option that is closest to the ground truth MCQ.

Upon re-reading the generated MCQs, I found that none of the questions exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a possible match based on the content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the requirements for producing electricity from nuclear power. While there isn't an exact match, Question 8 mentions nuclear power as an option for replacing fossil fuels.

However, I must note that this is not an exact match, and the correct answer is not explicitly present in the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that the closest match is not present, but if I had to choose from the given options, I would say that Question 8 is the closest, but it's not an exact match.

Index: 8 (Please note that this is not an exact match)

Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost

a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much electricity did the world use in the year 2020?
Options: A. 56 billion watts, B. 3 trillion watts, C. 1.5 trillion watts, D. 90 billion watts
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why electricity from any source requires space? Options: A. Because electricity generation involves the burning of fossil fuels., B. Because electricity generation requires the conversion of heat into electricity., C. Because electricity generation takes up physical space for equipment and infrastructure., D. Because electricity generation involves the storage of electrical energy. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, how much space would be required to power a 10-watt light bulb with fossil fuels like coal? Options: A. A square meter, B. A credit card-sized chunk of land, C. The size of a parking space, D. The area of Grand Bahama island Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the approximate area required to power the entire world with only fossil fuels? Options: A. 1,000 square kilometers, B. 1,200 square kilometers, C. 4,000 square kilometers, D. 95,000 square kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, how does the space needed for wind power generation vary compared to other power sources? Options: A. Wind power requires the most space of all power sources., B. Wind power requires the least space of all power sources., C. Wind power requires a significant amount of space, but not as much as nuclear power., D. Wind power requires space to be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 5: What are the two main considerations for choosing a power source, according to the transcript? Options: A. Space and cost, B. Space and greenhouse gas emissions, C. Cost and reliability, D. Space and availability Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the main challenge with relying on fossil fuels as a power source? Options: A. They require too much space., B. They are too expensive to build., C. They contribute to greenhouse gas emissions and climate change., D. They are not available in some places. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the amount of space needed for wind power generation and the efficiency of the turbines? Options: A. The more space, the higher the efficiency., B. The less space, the higher the efficiency., C. The space needed does not affect the efficiency of the turbines., D. The space needed must be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the best option for replacing fossil fuels in some places? Options: A. Nuclear power, B. Solar power, C. Wind power, D. A combination of power sources Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main consideration for making power sources better, according to the transcript? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increasing efficiency, C. Improving safety, D. Reducing costs Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the approximate percentage of greenhouse gas emissions that come from electricity generation? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 27%, D. 50% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not ask about the exact same information as the ground truth MCQ (electricity usage in 2020), it does ask about a related topic (space required to power the entire world with only fossil fuels) and provides a similar type of numerical answer. However, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable generated MCQ would be one that directly asks about the total electricity usage. Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs match the intent of the ground truth MCQ. If I had to choose one, I would say Question 3 is the closest, but I would recommend generating a new MCQ that directly asks about the total electricity usage.

However, if you'd like to create a new MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ more closely, here is an example:

Question: How much electricity did the world use, according to the transcript?
Options: A. 1.5 trillion watts, B. 3 trillion watts, C. 56 billion watts, D. 90 billion watts

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
No matter how we make electricity,
it takes up space. Electricity from coal requires mines,
and plants to burn it and convert the heat into electricity. Nuclear power takes uranium mines,
facilities to refine the uranium, a reactor, and a place to store 
the spent fuel safely. Renewable energy needs wind turbines 
or solar panels. How much space depends
on the power source. Say you wanted to power a 10-watt 
light bulb with fossil fuels like coal. Fossil fuels can produce 
up to 2,000 watts per square meter, so it would only take a credit card-sized
chunk of land to power the light bulb. With nuclear power, you might only
need an area about the size of the palms of your hands. With solar power, you’d need at least
0.3 square meters of land— twice the size of a cafeteria tray. Wind power would take roughly
7 square meters— about half the size of a parking space— 
to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost
four times as much space at a minimum— roughly 4,000 square kilometers, 
a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which power source uses the least amount of space?
Options: A. Solar power, B. Nuclear power, C. Fossil Fuels, D. Wind power
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why electricity from any source requires space? Options: A. Because electricity generation involves the burning of fossil fuels., B. Because electricity generation requires the conversion of heat into electricity., C. Because electricity generation takes up physical space for equipment and infrastructure., D. Because electricity generation involves the storage of electrical energy. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, how much space would be required to power a 10-watt light bulb with fossil fuels like coal? Options: A. A square meter, B. A credit card-sized chunk of land, C. The size of a parking space, D. The area of Grand Bahama island Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the approximate area required to power the entire world with only fossil fuels? Options: A. 1,000 square kilometers, B. 1,200 square kilometers, C. 4,000 square kilometers, D. 95,000 square kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, how does the space needed for wind power generation vary compared to other power sources? Options: A. Wind power requires the most space of all power sources., B. Wind power requires the least space of all power sources., C. Wind power requires a significant amount of space, but not as much as nuclear power., D. Wind power requires space to be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 5: What are the two main considerations for choosing a power source, according to the transcript? Options: A. Space and cost, B. Space and greenhouse gas emissions, C. Cost and reliability, D. Space and availability Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the main challenge with relying on fossil fuels as a power source? Options: A. They require too much space., B. They are too expensive to build., C. They contribute to greenhouse gas emissions and climate change., D. They are not available in some places. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the amount of space needed for wind power generation and the efficiency of the turbines? Options: A. The more space, the higher the efficiency., B. The less space, the higher the efficiency., C. The space needed does not affect the efficiency of the turbines., D. The space needed must be spread out to avoid reducing efficiency. Correct Option: D
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the best option for replacing fossil fuels in some places? Options: A. Nuclear power, B. Solar power, C. Wind power, D. A combination of power sources Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main consideration for making power sources better, according to the transcript? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increasing efficiency, C. Improving safety, D. Reducing costs Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the approximate percentage of greenhouse gas emissions that come from electricity generation? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 27%, D. 50% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. However, it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only compares the space required for fossil fuels to other options in the context of a 10-watt light bulb, rather than directly asking which power source uses the least amount of space.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly compares the space requirements of different power sources. Unfortunately, such a question is not present in the provided set.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set, I would choose Question 3's topic, but it compares the space requirements for powering the entire world, not which source uses the least amount of space in general.

But if I really had to choose from the provided set, I would say Question 2 is the closest match.

Index: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5

have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a breeze blows through the savannah, a snake-shaped tube stretches into the air
and scans the horizon like a periscope. But it’s not seeing— 
it’s sniffing for odors like the scent of a watering hole 
or the musk of a dangerous predator. The trunk’s owner 
is a young African elephant. At only 8 years old, she still has 
a lot to learn about her home. Fortunately, she’s not alone. Elephants are extremely social creatures, with females living in tight-knit herds 
led by a single matriarch. And every member of the group 
has one of the most versatile tools in the savannah to help them get by. Today her herd is looking for water. Or, more accurately, smelling for water. Elephants have more genes devoted 
to smell than any other creature, making them the best sniffers
in the animal kingdom. Even at our elephant’s young age,
her trunk is already 1.5 meters long and contains five times as many 
olfactory receptors as a human nose, allowing her to smell standing water
several kilometers away. And now, the matriarch uses her own keen
sense of smell to plot the herd’s course. Their journey is long,
so our elephant keeps her energy up by snacking on the occasional patch 
of thick grass. But this light lunch 
isn’t just about staying fed— she’s also looking for clues. Like many other mammals, vents in the roof of an elephant’s mouth 
lead directly to the vomeronasal organ. This structure can detect chemical
signals left by other elephants. So as the herd forages, 
they’re also gathering information about what other herds have come this way. All the while, the group’s adults are 
on the lookout for signs of other animals, including potential threats. Fortunately, while lions might attack
a young or sickly elephant, few are foolish enough to take 
on a healthy adult. Weighing 3 tons and bearing powerful tusks
nearly a meter long, our elephant’s mother is a force
to be reckoned with. Her dexterous trunk doubles 
as a powerful, flexible arm. Containing no bones
and an estimated 40,000 muscles, these agile appendages 
can bend, twist, contract, and expand. At 8 years old, our elephant’s trunk
is already strong enough to move small fallen trees, while finger-like extensions allow for 
delicate maneuvers like wiping her eye. She can even grab a nearby branch, break it to just the right length,
and wave off pesky insects. Suddenly, the matriarch stops their march
and sniffs the air. Using smell alone, elephants can recognize
each member of their herd, and their exceptional memories can 
retain the smells of elephants outside their herd as well. It’s one of these old but familiar odors
that’s caught the matriarch’s attention. She bellows into the air, sending out a sound wave 
that rings across the savannah. But it travels even further
through the earth as infrasonic rumbles. Elephants up to 10 kilometers away can
receive these rumbles with their feet. If the matriarch’s nose is right,
her herd should expect a response. Smelling the secretions 
from her daughter’s temporal glands, our elephant’s mother can sense 
her daughter’s unease about this unfamiliar encounter. As the herd of unknown
elephants approaches, trunks from both herds rise into the air,
sounding trumpets of alarm. But upon recognition, apprehension 
quickly gives way to happy rumbles. Members from each herd recognize
each other despite time apart, and many investigate each other’s mouths
with their trunks to smell what their counterparts 
have been eating. With the reunion now in full swing, both
herds head toward their final destination: the long-awaited watering hole. Here, older elephants suck up to 8 liters 
of water into their trunks before spraying the contents 
on themselves to cool off. Meanwhile, our young elephant plays 
in the mud with her peers, digging into the muck 
and even using her trunk as a snorkel to breathe while submerged. The pair of matriarchs look 
contentedly on their herds, before turning their trunks 
to the horizon once more.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Elephants have __________ olfactory receptors compared to humans.
Options: A. More, B. Less, C. About the same, D. No information was provided
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of an elephant's trunk? Options: A. To see and scan the horizon, B. To smell and detect odors, C. To breathe and inhale air, D. To walk and move around Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following is a unique feature of an elephant's sense of smell? Options: A. It is less sensitive than a human's sense of smell, B. It is more sensitive than a human's sense of smell, C. It is the same as a human's sense of smell, D. It is not present in elephants Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the vomeronasal organ in an elephant's mouth responsible for detecting? Options: A. Chemical signals left by other elephants, B. Visual signals left by other elephants, C. Auditory signals left by other elephants, D. Olfactory signals left by other elephants Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of an elephant's trunk when it is used to grab a nearby branch and wave off pesky insects? Options: A. To move small fallen trees, B. To wipe its eye, C. To grab a nearby branch and wave off pesky insects, D. To sniff the air Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do elephants recognize each member of their herd? Options: A. By visual cues, B. By auditory cues, C. By smell alone, D. By a combination of visual, auditory, and olfactory cues Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the purpose of the matriarch's infrasonic rumbles? Options: A. To communicate with other elephants over long distances, B. To scare away predators, C. To locate water sources, D. To mark territory Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the unique feature of an elephant's trunk that allows it to move small fallen trees? Options: A. Its length, B. Its flexibility, C. Its strength, D. Its ability to bend, twist, contract, and expand Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the purpose of an elephant's trunk when it is used to suck up water and spray it on itself to cool off? Options: A. To drink water, B. To cool off, C. To play in the mud, D. To investigate other elephants' mouths Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the unique feature of an elephant's temporal glands that allows its mother to sense its daughter's unease? Options: A. The secretion of a specific chemical signal, B. The presence of a specific odor, C. The absence of a specific odor, D. The presence of a specific visual cue Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the purpose of the reunion between the two herds of elephants? Options: A. To establish dominance, B. To find food, C. To recognize each other and investigate each other's mouths, D. To mark territory Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question is about the comparison of an elephant's sense of smell to a human's sense of smell, which is the same intent as the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 2 is "It is more sensitive than a human's sense of smell", which aligns with the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Elephants have more olfactory receptors compared to humans."

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2

and wave off pesky insects. Suddenly, the matriarch stops their march
and sniffs the air. Using smell alone, elephants can recognize
each member of their herd, and their exceptional memories can 
retain the smells of elephants outside their herd as well. It’s one of these old but familiar odors
that’s caught the matriarch’s attention. She bellows into the air, sending out a sound wave 
that rings across the savannah. But it travels even further
through the earth as infrasonic rumbles. Elephants up to 10 kilometers away can
receive these rumbles with their feet. If the matriarch’s nose is right,
her herd should expect a response. Smelling the secretions 
from her daughter’s temporal glands, our elephant’s mother can sense 
her daughter’s unease about this unfamiliar encounter. As the herd of unknown
elephants approaches, trunks from both herds rise into the air,
sounding trumpets of alarm. But upon recognition, apprehension 
quickly gives way to happy rumbles. Members from each herd recognize
each other despite time apart, and many investigate each other’s mouths
with their trunks to smell what their counterparts 
have been eating. With the reunion now in full swing, both
herds head toward their final destination: the long-awaited watering hole. Here, older elephants suck up to 8 liters 
of water into their trunks before spraying the contents 
on themselves to cool off. Meanwhile, our young elephant plays 
in the mud with her peers, digging into the muck 
and even using her trunk as a snorkel to breathe while submerged. The pair of matriarchs look 
contentedly on their herds, before turning their trunks 
to the horizon once more.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is an elephant trunk NOT used for
Options: A. Detecting odors, B. Drinking water, C. Gathering grasses or branches to eat, D. Attacking prey items like smaller animals to consume
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of an elephant's trunk? Options: A. To see and scan the horizon, B. To smell and detect odors, C. To breathe and inhale air, D. To walk and move around Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following is a unique feature of an elephant's sense of smell? Options: A. It is less sensitive than a human's sense of smell, B. It is more sensitive than a human's sense of smell, C. It is the same as a human's sense of smell, D. It is not present in elephants Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the vomeronasal organ in an elephant's mouth responsible for detecting? Options: A. Chemical signals left by other elephants, B. Visual signals left by other elephants, C. Auditory signals left by other elephants, D. Olfactory signals left by other elephants Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of an elephant's trunk when it is used to grab a nearby branch and wave off pesky insects? Options: A. To move small fallen trees, B. To wipe its eye, C. To grab a nearby branch and wave off pesky insects, D. To sniff the air Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do elephants recognize each member of their herd? Options: A. By visual cues, B. By auditory cues, C. By smell alone, D. By a combination of visual, auditory, and olfactory cues Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the purpose of the matriarch's infrasonic rumbles? Options: A. To communicate with other elephants over long distances, B. To scare away predators, C. To locate water sources, D. To mark territory Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the unique feature of an elephant's trunk that allows it to move small fallen trees? Options: A. Its length, B. Its flexibility, C. Its strength, D. Its ability to bend, twist, contract, and expand Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the purpose of an elephant's trunk when it is used to suck up water and spray it on itself to cool off? Options: A. To drink water, B. To cool off, C. To play in the mud, D. To investigate other elephants' mouths Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the unique feature of an elephant's temporal glands that allows its mother to sense its daughter's unease? Options: A. The secretion of a specific chemical signal, B. The presence of a specific odor, C. The absence of a specific odor, D. The presence of a specific visual cue Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the purpose of the reunion between the two herds of elephants? Options: A. To establish dominance, B. To find food, C. To recognize each other and investigate each other's mouths, D. To mark territory Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a breeze blows through the savannah, a snake-shaped tube stretches into the air
and scans the horizon like a periscope. But it’s not seeing— 
it’s sniffing for odors like the scent of a watering hole 
or the musk of a dangerous predator. The trunk’s owner 
is a young African elephant. At only 8 years old, she still has 
a lot to learn about her home. Fortunately, she’s not alone. Elephants are extremely social creatures, with females living in tight-knit herds 
led by a single matriarch. And every member of the group 
has one of the most versatile tools in the savannah to help them get by. Today her herd is looking for water. Or, more accurately, smelling for water. Elephants have more genes devoted 
to smell than any other creature, making them the best sniffers
in the animal kingdom. Even at our elephant’s young age,
her trunk is already 1.5 meters long and contains five times as many 
olfactory receptors as a human nose, allowing her to smell standing water
several kilometers away. And now, the matriarch uses her own keen
sense of smell to plot the herd’s course. Their journey is long,
so our elephant keeps her energy up by snacking on the occasional patch 
of thick grass. But this light lunch 
isn’t just about staying fed— she’s also looking for clues. Like many other mammals, vents in the roof of an elephant’s mouth 
lead directly to the vomeronasal organ. This structure can detect chemical
signals left by other elephants. So as the herd forages, 
they’re also gathering information about what other herds have come this way. All the while, the group’s adults are 
on the lookout for signs of other animals, including potential threats. Fortunately, while lions might attack
a young or sickly elephant, few are foolish enough to take 
on a healthy adult. Weighing 3 tons and bearing powerful tusks
nearly a meter long, our elephant’s mother is a force
to be reckoned with. Her dexterous trunk doubles 
as a powerful, flexible arm. Containing no bones
and an estimated 40,000 muscles, these agile appendages 
can bend, twist, contract, and expand. At 8 years old, our elephant’s trunk
is already strong enough to move small fallen trees, while finger-like extensions allow for 
delicate maneuvers like wiping her eye. She can even grab a nearby branch, break it to just the right length,
and wave off pesky insects. Suddenly, the matriarch stops their march
and sniffs the air. Using smell alone, elephants can recognize
each member of their herd, and their exceptional memories can 
retain the smells of elephants outside their herd as well. It’s one of these old but familiar odors
that’s caught the matriarch’s attention. She bellows into the air, sending out a sound wave 
that rings across the savannah. But it travels even further
through the earth as infrasonic rumbles. Elephants up to 10 kilometers away can
receive these rumbles with their feet. If the matriarch’s nose is right,
her herd should expect a response. Smelling the secretions 
from her daughter’s temporal glands, our elephant’s mother can sense 
her daughter’s unease about this unfamiliar encounter. As the herd of unknown
elephants approaches, trunks from both herds rise into the air,
sounding trumpets of alarm. But upon recognition, apprehension 
quickly gives way to happy rumbles. Members from each herd recognize
each other despite time apart, and many investigate each other’s mouths
with their trunks to smell what their counterparts 
have been eating. With the reunion now in full swing, both
herds head toward their final destination: the long-awaited watering hole. Here, older elephants suck up to 8 liters 
of water into their trunks before spraying the contents 
on themselves to cool off. Meanwhile, our young elephant plays 
in the mud with her peers, digging into the muck 
and even using her trunk as a snorkel to breathe while submerged. The pair of matriarchs look 
contentedly on their herds, before turning their trunks 
to the horizon once more.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Female elephants live in social groups led by
Options: A. The three or four oldest individuals, B. A male who serves as the equivalent of a horse “stallion” to lead the herd, C. The eldest female known as a matriarch, D. Group decision making in which all individuals provide input on the decision
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The vomeronasal organ is common to many mammals and plays a major role in
Options: A. Detecting predators, B. Evaluating the reproductive status of conspecifics (other members of the same species), C. Determining the location of food or water, D. Warning other animals about danger
Correct Option: B
